item.title: Biofeedback - Migraine, TTH
item.description:
#migraine
Based on the association an individual develops with physical and actual sensations to consciously take actions. They're taken based upon the 'feedback' provided through EMG/EDG/Thermal etc. means.

item.title: Interactions for Industrial Design
item.description:
Often times industrial design is done with considerations of how it looks, feels and functions in a context. How can we think about making products more discursively?
Is there a way to simplify aspects of interactions for designing tangible products

item.title: Knowledge
item.description:
Nature of knowledge: Known, embodied, understood, learnt?
How do we know what we know?
What systems there are in the 'how' of knowing what we know?
The scientific methods?
What else?
Can there be new ways of discovering the world?
For young learners?
For people who want to be a generalist?

item.title: Roughly
item.description:
#Healthcare #InteractionParadigm
#Healthcare
//Diagnostics
Visual/Auditory/Tactile/Data
Are there gaps in diagnostic abilities posed by artifacts, or lack there of, or by behaviours they promote or inhibit?
//Non-Pharmacological Pain Management
Headaches (Migraine, Cluster & TTH) , Podiatry
Headaches and Podiatry are fields that are not completely understood and that often surfaces in being able to prescribe appropriate treatment (big claim). In the given state of these medical conditions, are there possibilities of certain tools existing that could help alleviate pain faced by individuals living with it?
//Pain Vocabulary
Appropriate descriptions and correlations with other indicators could lead to appropriate diagnosis and treatment. However, the vocabulary for pain description is often a combination of verbal, visual and gestural descriptors. Is there a need / ways that could evolve into tools to improve the capacity of describing and expressing pain (to improve ability to diagnose)?
//Biofeedback
A fairly well-studied type of therapy that relies on developed associations between actual physical sensations and numbers returned by devices that monitor body-signals. Trained and used with the guidance of professionals to develop a habit.
//Sense-making of Biomarkers
Individuals use various tools that track their vital signs or monitor their vitals through modelled data. However, what this means for them and what the data means for them is prescribed by software that is developed to communicate what is understood to be important the consumer.
//Podiatry Care
For improving foot posture health and gait, there are devices in the market that cater to footprint analysis, but is the angle at the ankle an important indicator by any means
//EMG for Ergonomics
Can muscle stress levels be accurately understood for better sense-making of ergonomic features of an object or activity?
//Play
What is learning through play and how can it be facilitated?
//Sense-making of hematology reports
#InteractionParadigm
//Air Mouse
Remote ways to navigate on a digital screen
//Projector + Camera
For spatial computing hobbyists?

changes easily depending on context, losing weight, identifying fit with some perceptions

edema in ankle, feet and shin
pointed out overweight
took test for PCOD
insulin was higher
physical vanity
look fit
tried out so many things discomfort around body
setting goals
KPoP dances everyday
look good doing it
doesn't like being forced to
skip meals too busy
corelation between food and fitness
journalling felt pressure initially, system to do it frequently
productivity, overwhelming
joined gym briefly, forced to fall asleep pretty early, schedule didnt allow
pure pain
one incovenience can make things worse, nothing to monitor.

forces from and within the body

item.title: Physical Intelligence - Noah Riskin
item.description:
Director of PI at MIT for 10 years
Primary Idea -
' More, the level of physical intelligence we possess, e.g., our ability to notice and respond to a nuanced range of bodily perceptions, signals and cues, is fundamentally important to social cognition, such as when we self-referentially infer the intentions and behavior of other people.'
He constitutes physical intelligence as a means of understanding and discovering the world around us.
Physical Intelligence course from 2002
Primary Components: Spatial Perception, Complex Coordination, Proprioception

item.title: Week 1 & 2
item.description:
Where I started:
Different areas of focus within healthcare - Standards of care for Migraines & TTH, Diagnostic Tools, Physical Pain Management, Podiatry
For creatives - EMG for ergonomics, or just how ergonomics is done in general, what can play look like for individuals?
Where I am:
Interested in Healthcare, life sciences and general wellbeing, might find access to relevant stakeholders
Standards of Care for Migraine Brainstorming - Migraine & TTH Care
Sleep Health SleepHealth.excalidraw
Fitness/Rehabilitation at homes MapOfEverything.excalidraw
First Aid Typologies
Physical Intelligence PhysicalIntelligence.excalidraw
Improving/Augmenting observational capabilities
Also re-found a few areas of interest,
Curiosity as a behaviour, how can it be leveraged in the context of learning?
How might we enable play in the phygital medium?
What does play-led interaction design look like?
Areas that might or could possibly converge,

Physical Intelligence + Fitness/Rehab + Observational Capacity
Curiosity + Phygital Play + Play-led IxD
Supposed first-leg:

Begin interacting with people on both the fronts (Designers and Educators for what enables curiosity, People in the fitness industry for physical intelligence)
First-Aid - Get in touch with paramedics
GP updates
1. Neurology Front: Call (Space of Migraine care/TTH care (diagnostics, everyday life, pain management upon episode, difference between episodic and chronic, understood and accepted pathophysiology: Philosophy of where I’m coming from, to improve patient outcomes at whatever capacity possible) 2. What worries you? : (Activity as a means of discovering areas to work with, general gathering and probing and grouping to see if patterns emerge) 3. Developing Interactions for Designers: Tactile, Haptic, Motion, Audio. In what ways can designing for these senses be made easier? Are we designing a tool? A means to a tool? What are we implicating? Do products like this exist? Is this experimental or catered as a product offering to designers? 4. Play through hardware: Is there a way to make making phygital interactions easier? Is there a way to develop tools that can enable faster making of games and other interactions that could A. Inform design practice B. Improve or expand existing modalities of play
Things made in service of others
Things made for the sake of them to exist

item.title: Week 3
item.description:
Area of Work: Physical Wellbeing
Specificities: Forefront-ing physical intelligence at the junctures of injury-recovery cycles, certain chronic conditions, elderly care and general wellbeing.
Core Belief: Physical intelligence (PI) is the ability of the body's technology to function and adapt in the physical world. Leveraging understanding of & targeted training/evaluating PI could prove to be beneficial in specific contexts.
From the neuroscience perspective,
PI is the result of cognitive capabilities, biological information processing and biomechanics working in tandem.
From the psychology-arts perspective,
PI is the means through which we interact and navigate the physical world.
From the embodied AI perspective,
PI is the combination of visual perception, workflow planning and causal models.
From the physical wellbeing perspective,
PI is composed of proprioceptive abilities, strength & mobility, reflex & coordination.
Primary Hope: Improve quality of physical assessments, recovery & monitoring biomechanical and cognitive functions.
Secondary Hope: Improve capacity to identify cognitive & biomechanical decline early on, reduce risk of injury in routine tasks & identify potential developmental challenges relating to motor-skills and mobility.
Tertiary Hope: Improve overall motivation quotient for wellbeing.
Things to do:
Relevant Stakeholders: Conversation/Interviews

Identify what it means to individuals to stay fit
Core motivations and their sources to stay fit/healthy
Physiotherapists, Orthopedics, Geriatric Care Centers, Child Developmental Care Centers
Understanding Landscape

Futures of health & wellbeing - Lifestyle and living condition
Healthcare expenditure, indirect costs, proportion of disposable income spent

item.title: Week 4
item.description:
Focus:
Physical Intelligence: A set of abilities and capacities that utilise technology of the physical body to interact with the world in a versatile and resilient manner.
Physical Wellbeing: The means through which physical intelligence is leveraged.
Groups of people to whom leveraging physical intelligence can be critical:

Children aged 3 - 12 : Can fully understand what the human body is capable of while building their roots in listening to their body, and developing best practices in physical wellbeing through play
Older Adults 55 - 65: Can understand and monitor their physical capacities over time to be able to identify early indicators of biomechanical development of a disorder, improve health outcomes by minimising friction to being physically active
Individuals who have suffered an injury: Can augment abilities to monitor changes over time, understand recovery and progress.
Approach:

Behavioural Layer: Core motivations of individuals in relation to physical wellbeing
Experiential / Functional needs: People & Experts (Physiotherapists, Geriatric Care Specialists, Child Developmental Centers)
